PROCTEXT.PARA: That the bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Reid The Hon N.B.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy Speaker, I take the opportunity to wish you well in your new role in this chamber and I hope that the conduct of the chamber continues at the high level set yesterday. The Corporations Legislation Amendment Bill 1994 is a very important bill for non-banking financial institutions. Presently, the activities of financial institutions, principally building societies and credit unions, are regulated by the Corporations Law as well as by state and territory financial institutions legislation.

PARA.TAB: The ministerial councils for corporations and for financial institutions have agreed on the principles by which the interface between the Corporations Law and the financial institutions legislation is to be rationalised. The rationalisation will remove any doubts and uncertainties for financial institutions as to which law applies to their activities. It will also remove any regulatory duplication and reduce the associated administrative burden.

I have had indication that the aim of the bill is to clear up the conflicting areas between Corporations Law and acts, such as the financial institutions code. If this bill is passed, it would establish that Corporations Law does not apply to building society or credit union activities of, firstly, issuing withdrawable shares, and, secondly, collecting deposits. It would apply to other activities; for example, the provision of ancillary services such as ADFs, bonds, superannuation, et cetera. Also, it would apply to the issue of shares to special service providers.

Once established, the Corporations Law does apply to all other capital raisings—such as share issues and note issues—and it clarifies that non-bank financial institutions do not need an ARBN, a registered business number, to operate interstate, but it still means that building societies and credit unions may need some identification number for prospectuses.

I want to declare my interest in the Bendigo Building Society. The Bendigo Building Society is pleased to support the bill that the government has brought forward, as it clears up the ambiguity as to which law applies—the financial institutions code or the Corporations Law—to normal, day-to-day operations as opposed to capital-type raising. I want to comment briefly on the financial worthiness of a couple of organisations within my electorate. One is the Bendigo Building Society and the other is North West Country Credit. North West Country Credit has recently recorded a very successful year. It recorded a $615,000 12 months profit, unaudited at this stage, in the year to 31 March. The manager, Mr John Hall, said that the result was following great support from Bendigonians. He said:

SPEECH.PARA: It was the best 12-month result in the credit union's 33-year history.
The past 12 months have seen a tremendous growth in our lending as well as quality borrowers being attracted to the local aspect of the credit union.
We've seen a strong and steady growth in deposits in the last 12 months which exemplifies the feeling of confidence in the economy.

I also want to give brief background details of the worthiness of the Bendigo Building Society. It was established in 1858 as a terminating building society, and is probably the oldest building society in Australia. In 1865 it was re-formed as a permanent building society and has continued in that role. It is a member of the Australian Association of Permanent Building Societies and plays a leading role in that association. It has had a very impressive history. It has survived some very traumatic events. In 1884 the society issued permanent paid-up shares which were non-withdrawable. This was the start of the society's policy of having a base of capital which supported depositors' investment in the Bendigo Building Society. The big bust in 1893, after the housing boom, closed many other societies and some banks in Australia, but the Bendigo society, being based on bricks and mortar, was as sound as a bell and continued to pay dividends right through that period.

PARA.TAB: A number of other building societies were established, including the Bendigo and Eaglehawk Star Building Society and the Sandhurst Building Society. In 1942 the Bendigo Building Society reached $1 million in assets. It merged with the Bendigo and Eaglehawk Star Building Society. Total assets in 1978 were $112 million and it had two branches. I know it will be of interest to you, Mr Deputy Speaker, that the Perth Building Society attempted to take over the Bendigo Building Society in 1981, but I am pleased to report that that offer was repulsed. The Bendigo society then merged with the Sandhurst Building Society to form a society with total assets of $264 million. That was in 1983.

The Pyramid Building Society collapse was a traumatic event not only for Victoria but also for Australia. It meant a lapse in confidence in building societies to some extent. Despite this, the Bendigo Building Society weathered the storm from its own resources. In 1991 the society acquired the Sandhurst Trustees, an old, established trustee company in Bendigo. In 1992, as part of a rationalisation of the building societies industry, post Farrow and Pyramid Building Society collapse, Bendigo acquired the Capital Building Society in Geelong and the Compass Building Society in Dandenong. At present, the Bendigo Building Society's total assets exceed $1.4 billion. It has 76 branches throughout Victoria and over 370,000 accounts. Client funds invested in the group, including Sandhurst Trustees, total $1.7 billion.

So you can understand, Mr Deputy Speaker, how important it is that there be no ambiguity in the Corporations Law, so that these two fine financial organisations based in Bendigo can understand exactly which law applies to their activities.

The question of superannuation has been raised by the Australian Association of Permanent Building Societies, which has been greatly concerned about the government's efforts in superannuation. The association has come up with a unique way to address this, by establishing a superannuation savings account which could be handled by building societies throughout Australia. The societies are desirous that the Corporations Law would cover them in that respect as well so that there would be no ambiguity in terms of their operations. The association has put a suggestion to the government as follows:

SPEECH.PARA: .The accounts would be subject to the preservation and other requirements applying to superannuation savings generally and to preferential taxation treatment.
.The accounts would not require a trust deed or be subject to expensive prospectus requirements. Contributions would be deposits made with the society.
.Simple plain English terms and conditions to apply with ISC standards would be contained in records of the account which would be either a simple passbook or regular statement account style.

Honourable members in this chamber would be aware of the complications for itinerant workers and casual workers when they pay into a superannuation fund and suddenly find, at the end of a period, that the contributions which have been deducted from their earnings have vanished because of charges made by the superannuation fund. The suggestion continues:
The distinction between SSAs—
superannuation savings accounts—

and normal savings accounts would be emphasised and drawn to the attention of members. Ease and simplicity of deposit making would be a feature using the branch network, direct crediting system and ATMs—
automatic teller machines—

.No special or extra fees would apply to SSA savings accounts with building societies. No entry or exit fees would apply nor would the "flat rate" or "weekly charges", so common in many current superannuation plans. The full amount of savings (less 15% taxation) contributed would be available to grow at market interest rates.
That would overcome the problem of charges eating away and eroding the payments made under the government's system. The suggestion continues:
.Building societies are subject to uniform and high prudential standards of the Australian Financial Institutions Commission and to the inspection system of the State Supervisory Authorities.
.Societies would offer the SSA holder the option to switch into a complying managed superannuation fund of the depositor's choice at any time. No exit fees would apply.

The societies would not favour any constraint on switching of superannuation savings accounts to superannuation savings accounts in other institutions. Again no exit or entry fees would apply. The suggestion continues:

.The industry does not favour a uniform maximum cap being placed on SSA accounts. We recommend an ISC requirement that SSA contributors be compulsorily offered managed and growth options by the society each year their account exceeds a balance of $20,000.

.The interest rate offered on SSAs would be the current market rate prevailing for saving accounts with clear potential for societies in a competitive environment to offer more attractive rates as the account reaches threshold levels and as it reflects a more stable form of genuine saving than say transaction accounts. In a competitive market each society would determine its policy in this regard.

I wanted to establish the worthiness of those two organisations in Bendigo, the Bendigo Building Society and North West Country Credit. Both of those organisations are supporting the legislation currently before this chamber. I recognise that it will remove the doubts and any uncertainties from the operations of those non-banking financial institutions as to which law applies to their activities. That will be in the best interests of their customers, their clients, their borrowers, their lenders—anyone that is involved in that industry needs to have an assurance of being able to operate in an area where there is no ambiguity and no conflict of interest. This bill which is brought before the parliament would give that assurance.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Slipper Mr P.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —Like many of my colleagues, this will be my maiden speech in this particular place. I must comment that the atmosphere is really quite different from the other place. It reminds me somewhat of the Northern Territory parliament. I notice from looking at yesterday's Hansard that the interjections appear to be almost conversational. That is caused by the fact that we are all fairly close together here. Perhaps that is a good thing and perhaps, in some cases, it is not.

PARA.TAB: I am pleased to join the debate in relation to the Corporations Legislation Amendment Bill 1994. This is another omnibus bill. It seems to me that in the parliament we are now having more and more omnibus bills introduced whereby many acts of the parliament are amended. Those acts in many cases do not have any real relationship with one another but, for reasons of convenience, everything is lumped together into the one bill with the result that changes are made at one vote in the parliament.

Some of the amendments in this legislation include: conferring civil jurisdiction under the Corporations Act 1989 and the Corporations Law on lower courts in areas of monetary compensation and debt recovery; introducing the final stage of legislative support for an enhanced electronic settlement system; and extending the application of the fundraising provisions of the Corporations Law to financial institutions, namely, building societies and credit unions. My colleague the honourable member for Bendigo (Mr Reid) outlined his interest in that particular aspect of the legislation just a moment ago, and he outlined it very well.

The legislation excludes the rules of natural justice from procedures to be observed in hearings by the Corporations and Securities Panel and introduces a system of penalty points, $100 per unit, in lieu of reference to a penalty expressed in a dollar amount. The amendments also seek to enable the conversion of certain companies limited by shares to no liability companies.

According to the explanatory memorandum before the committee, these amendments are claimed to be necessary to advance the simplification of the Corporations Law. It is admitted that that exercise will take `some little time'. When one looks at the Corporations Law of Australia and one looks at the taxation laws of Australia, it is very clear that these very bulky acts need simplification. To be honest, my impression has been that the parliament has been moving in the wrong direction in that it appears that the Corporations Law is being made ever more complex. One would hope that the government will indeed take on board the very laudable aim of simplifying the law to make it easy for individuals and citizens to know just how the law affects them.

I spoke earlier this year on the Corporate Law Reform Bill 1993, which basically was to provide for the ongoing disclosure of certain financial information to the Australian Securities Commission by certain entities. During my speech on that bill, I called for the government to give priority to simplifying the Corporations Law and harmonising it to economic objectives. I would welcome any attempt to simplify the complex and cumbersome Corporations Law. I wonder whether the government has yet taken any steps in this direction.

The Bills Digest suggests that the amendments contained in the Corporations Legislation Amendment Bill will help keep the Corporations Law current and streamline the operations of the Australian Securities Commission. I do hope that is correct. The bill will also make a number of other miscellaneous amendments.

I would now like to give a brief description of some of the provisions contained in the bill. Part 1 of the bill relates to the conferral of jurisdiction on lower courts. Recently there have been court decisions ruling that lower courts do not have jurisdiction to hear civil claims made under the Corporations Law. The concern stemming from this relates to the fact that many legitimate civil claims may not be pursued under the Corporations Law because of the high cost of bringing actions in superior courts. The problem is compounded by the reluctance of superior courts to consider minor claims. I think most people in society realise that the cost of justice is a major worry and hopefully the amendments contained in this bill to confer some jurisdiction on lower courts will bring the law within the reach of more people.

The amendments confer on lower courts, including intermediate courts in each state and territory, civil jurisdiction in respect of corporate law claims relating to debt recovery or monetary compensation. However, civil jurisdiction will not be granted to lower courts where high level discretionary powers are involved. The coalition is not opposing this amendment.

The second section relates to the introduction of the clearing house electronic subregister system—CHESS. The Corporations Law provides a legislative framework for the electronic settlement of transactions on the Australian Stock Exchange. Amendments to the provision contained in the Corporations Law facilitate the use of CHESS. The aim of CHESS is to have transactions settled and delivered within three days after trade and to replace the current paper document of transfer with electronic transfer.

Further technical amendments to support the introduction of CHESS include facilitating electronic acceptance of takeover offers and allowing companies to set cut-off dates for voting purposes in respect of quoted securities. This amendment is also not being opposed by the coalition.

The bill also introduces amendments which affect the application of the Corporations Law to financial institutions. Currently, the Corporations Law has an uneven application to financial institutions and, in particular, building societies and credit unions, which are mainly regulated by the law enacted by the parliaments in the states and territories.

The amendments will have the following consequences: fundraising provisions of the Corporations Law will apply to financial institutions with certain specified exceptions such as withdrawable shares, deposit taking and other circumstances in which the provisions would not apply if the fundraiser were a bank. The coalition, again, is not opposing this amendment but it is worth noting that the removal of charges over the property of financial institutions from the Corporations Law registration scheme will worsen the fragmentation of personal property security registration in this nation—and that is, indeed, a major worry.

Part 4 of the bill contains amendments to the Australian Securities Commission Act 1989 and the Corporations Law in relation to the functions of the Corporations and Securities Panel which examines matters such as corporate takeovers and can make a declaration of unacceptable conduct. The panel's jurisdiction will be extended to cover matters concerned with takeover conduct generally, and the legislative procedures for the conduct of panel hearings will be amended to specify what constitutes procedural fairness in inquiries.

The bill aims to remedy substantive and procedural difficulties which have been identified with the panel. The panel was set up under the ASC Act and faults were identified when the first application came before the panel. The faults included that the procedures did not discourage time wasting litigation, the requirements of natural justice allegedly hindered the panel from coming to quick decisions, the panel's jurisdiction was too limited and the panel could not enforce undertakings given by parties. I am somewhat concerned about these changes contained in this bill.

Part 4 of this bill excludes the rules of natural justice in relation to an inquiry, excludes legal and other advisers from representing persons appearing before the panel—they can be present but are not allowed to address the panel. The panel will also be allowed to enforce undertakings given by parties and the jurisdiction of the panel will be broadened to enable the investigation of certain conduct relating to takeovers.

I have always personally supported the principle of procedural fairness and natural justice. Not only in our society should justice be done; it must be seen to be done. Once society loses confidence that, indeed, justice is being done, then we find that our whole system very rapidly will become unstuck. The rules of natural justice provide a standard for ensuring fairness, and their exclusion should be very carefully considered. Natural justice safeguards the rights of people who may be affected by an administrative or quasi-judicial decision to procedural fairness in the making of the decision.

The rules of natural justice have been used by courts for centuries. There are two main principles involved. A decision maker should give a person affected by a decision the chance to be heard—that is very important—and a decision maker should not be biased. The rules of natural justice form a part of the common law, and they are there to ensure procedural fairness. They are based on commonsense and common decency, in a democracy where people's human rights are fully understood and accepted.

The rules of natural justice are so well known to the legal system that very clear and specific wording must be inserted into a statute, if natural justice is to be excluded. Item 20 in schedule 4 of the Corporations Legislation Amendment Bill 1994 contains an amendment which would insert a revised section 195 in the Corporations Law. The proposed new section will end with these words: `The rules of natural justice do not apply in relation to an inquiry.' Clearly, those very important and clear words will remove those fundamental rules.

It is suggested that regulations to be made under the Corporations Law will provide substitute procedures for the rules of natural justice. I am not for a moment saying that the Attorney-General (Mr Lavarch) and the government are not serious in stating that these regulations will indeed be made in due course. But I do not think that it is right to exclude natural justice before there is an alternative procedure in place. I believe that those replacement safeguards should be detailed in the primary legislation. It is a tragedy and it is quite wrong that the government has omitted those replacement safeguards from the primary legislation.

If the government does intend to include these safeguards in regulations, why could it not have prepared those safeguards and then put them into this legislation so that, when we come before this committee debating this very important bill, we know that when people's rights are being taken away there will be substitute rights which will ensure that they are not being disadvantaged? We have not seen what the substitute procedures are going to be, and it therefore remains to be seen whether the substitute procedures will be sufficient to equate with the situation in the past, where natural justice has protected people.

In the case of Sir Matthew Harris against the Municipal Council of Sydney, admittedly a long time ago, in 1912, it was found that the local government authority was required to give the owner the opportunity to be heard before a building was demolished. As honourable members can see, if the council had gone ahead and demolished the building without giving the person the opportunity to be heard, then clearly the building could not be reconstructed. Thus natural justice was essential.

If we are going to demolish these fundamental safeguards, which have been entrenched in our legal systems for a very long period of time, then we ought to know what is going to be put into the system to replace them. The explanatory memorandum to the Corporations Legislation Amendment Bill 1994 says that the rules of natural justice will be replaced by procedures prescribed in regulations. It is about time the government told us what these are going to be. The Attorney-General might be able to let us know when he replies to this debate.

The panel's main hearing to date has been the Titan Hills case, which is said to involve the panel in excessive deliberations arising from the rules of natural justice. This might possibly be the reason that we are finding the amendment being made in the legislation. Sir William Wade, the noted English author of the classic legal text, Administrative Law, which was undoubtedly the bane of many law students, said:

SPEECH.PARA: Lawyers are a procedurally minded race, and it is natural that administrators should be tempted to regard procedural restrictions invented by lawyers as an obstacle to efficiency. It is true that the rules of natural justice restrict the freedom of administrative action and that their observance costs a certain amount of time and money. But time and money are likely to be well spent if they reduce friction in the machinery of government, and it is because they are essentially rules for upholding fairness and so reducing grievances that the rules of natural justice can be said to promote efficiency rather than impede it.
I hope the government bears this in mind when it looks at the drafting of its replacement safeguards.

PARA.TAB: Another part of the bill includes the ban on legal representatives addressing the panel. This worries me. Of course, in society we have people who have uneven abilities. It is a democratic right in a free society that, if a person is unable to speak adequately on his or her own behalf, that person should be able to retain legally trained people to do that. Some undemocratic regimes in other parts of the world deny people legal representation, and it is worrying to find that the government is inserting that kind of provision in this legislation.

I might add that the ban on legal representatives addressing the panel has also been criticised by the Australian Institute of Company Directors, on the grounds that lawyers should have the right to address the panel on matters which affect the legal rights of a party called before the panel, because of the range of orders that can be made by the panel. Quite clearly, the panel will have a great deal of power and will be able to make decisions which impact very seriously on the rights of individuals. If those individuals are not able to put forward a case before the panel adequately then it is pretty clear that justice will not be done. The coalition, of course, is opposing this particular amendment. The coalition is opposing aspects of the bill because we are saying that procedural fairness should be included in the primary legislation, and also that a person appearing before the panel should be able to have someone else speak on his or her behalf.

A further amendment contained in the bill deals with the notification of review of a Securities Commission decision. This section of the bill contains amendments to the Administrative Appeals Tribunal Act 1975, the Australian Securities Commission Act 1989 and the Corporations Law. The amendments exempt, under certain circumstances, the ASC from notifying all persons whose interests are affected by a reviewable decision. The proposed amendments place an onus on the ASC to take reasonable steps to notify people affected by an ASC decision. The ASC, in doing so, can consider costs involved in notification, how the person will be affected and whether notice is warranted under the circumstances. The coalition is not opposing this amendment. It would be advisable for the ASC to issue a statement listing the categories of people to whom it might consider giving notice, and representations could then be made to the ASC by interested parties.

This bill also provides for the establishment of stock markets in unquoted prescribed interests on which the interests may be traded by means of an electronic trading facility. This will require ministerial approval. The Australian Stock Exchange claims the amendments do not go far enough in providing for an efficient market and ensuring that the public interest is safeguarded. Again, the coalition is not opposing this amendment. However, the government should closely monitor the operations of this amendment in light of the Australian Stock Exchange concern.

The bill also provides amendments to the definitions of `securities' and `futures contract' and concern has been expressed by legal practitioners, academics and people involved in the industry over this proposal. I understand this proposal will allow for consideration to be given to trading on the Australian stock and futures markets of specified kinds of agreements which may not fall squarely with the current definitions of `securities' or `futures contract'. There has not been sufficient time for consideration of the concerns raised by lawyers and others. The amendments were not contained in the exposure draft of the bill and the coalition is not happy with this amendment either. We would really like to see it have further consideration.

This bill also allows companies limited by shares to convert to no liability status. This allows companies to offer shares at a discount without a requirement to obtain court approval for the offer, thereby making the investment more attractive. Currently a no liability company, which is usually a mining company, can convert to a limited liability company but cannot convert in the other direction. The amendment deals with an irregularity which has caused problems for the mining industry; and the coalition is not opposing this.

There are a number of other minor amendments proposed in the bill. It applies penalty units to the Corporations Law and the ASC Act, allowing for pecuniary penalties imposed by national scheme laws to be varied more easily. It transfers responsibility for unclaimed money and property from the minister to the ASC. It enables certificates of incorporation of a company and registration of a charge to be used in courts outside the state or territory in which the company is incorporated. Other non-contentious amendments include facilitating the trading on the Australian Stock Exchange of options over unissued shares. Also, the legislation amends the provision concerning the making of declarations of exempt futures markets to ensure that the conditions of declarations may be enforced.

While this is a bill where the coalition is not opposing many of the provisions, I have however outlined concerns that we have. I hope that the government favourably considers those concerns and acts on them, if not in this piece of legislation then in a subsequent bill to be brought before the parliament.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Pyne Mr C.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy Speaker, as it is the first time I have spoken in the Main Committee, may I take this opportunity to congratulate you on your appointment as Deputy Speaker being responsible for the Main Committee.

PARA.TAB: The Corporations Legislation Amendment Bill seeks to improve the operations of the Corporations Law, the Australian Securities Commission and the Corporations and Securities Panel. The government has foreshadowed a simplification of the current legislation but warned that it will take `some little time to produce results', to quote the government. It has designed these amendments to streamline its functions while this review is under way.

Key reforms included in the bill include: the conferral of civil jurisdiction under the Corporations Law on lower courts; amendments that will support the introduction of the clearing house electronic subregister system, or CHESS; an extension of the application of the Corporations Law to building societies and credit unions; the establishment of a modified regime to notify persons affected by ASC decisions of their rights of review; provision for the establishment and regulation of markets in unquoted prescribed interests using screen based trading systems, which I am sure you are familiar with, Mr Deputy Speaker; and the varying of the application of the rules of natural justice from proceedings heard by the Corporations and Securities Panel.

As the honourable member for Tangney (Mr Williams) said yesterday, the Liberal Party supports most of these measures. The current uncertainty over the ability of district and county courts to hear claims under the Corporations Law may discourage legitimate but small civil claims from being heard, especially when the reluctance of superior courts to consider minor claims is taken into account. The CHESS system will be able to speedily settle and deliver transactions and offer an electronic replacement for the current paper document of transfer.

We largely welcome the application of Corporations Law to financial institutions, although we are concerned that the government has chosen to reject the Australian Law Reform Commission recommendations from last year to simplify personal property security registration systems.
The notification of review of decisions provisions will help overcome the difficult practical problems the ASC faces in identifying all of the persons affected by its broader ranging decisions.

The Australian Stock Exchange has expressed reservations over the amendments in schedule 8 of the bill providing for the establishment of stock markets in unquoted prescribed interests traded by electronic means. The ASX has been concerned that the amendments do not provide a sufficient framework for an efficient market and for the protection of investors, especially those smaller ones at whom this type of market is directed, making it important for the government to closely monitor the operations of this market.

The Liberal Party, however, does have significant concerns with the changes to the Corporations and Securities Panel contained in section 4 of the bill. The Attorney-General (Mr Lavarch) is more than a little coy about these changes in his explanatory memorandum, and I note he is present today. Section 4, we read, that the legislation will `better equip it to fulfil its legislative charter of making timely commercial decisions in relation to takeovers' and extend its jurisdiction to takeover conduct generally. When we come to the section that offers more detail, the minister peeps out shyly from behind his little round spectacles—

TALK.START.PARA: —Shyly!
—And he adds:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . the legislative procedures for the conduct of Panel hearings set out in the Australian Securities Commission Act 1989 . . . will be amended to specify with greater precision what constitutes procedural fairness for the purpose of the Panel's inquiries.

What he is actually telling us is that section 4 will virtually exclude the rules of natural justice in relation to inquiries, regardless of the amendment that the government moved yesterday, a move that should always be cause for concern. The amendments may end procedural fairness in the panel's operations.

PARA.TAB: It is important to look at the panel's background and its operations before discussing this point further. The Corporations and Securities Panel was established under the 1989 ASC Act. The panel was supposed to be similar to the London Takeovers Panel. This body is a voluntary panel made up of all large business and service organisations in the City of London through which all major takeovers proceed.

It was envisaged that the panel would act as a peer review body which would be able to come to quick decisions on matters relating to takeovers to ensure that participants and affected parties and shareholders could make decisions on the basis of full information. As such, the panel was composed almost entirely of people with significant business experience, so commercial matters such as takeovers could be dealt with in a commercial—rather than legalistic—fashion by people such as merchant bankers and corporate solicitors rather than judges.

The panel operated independently of the ASC. The ASC was to refer matters to the panel when it considered that unacceptable behaviour may have occurred, and the panel would review the matter and decide whether or not to make a declaration and to issue orders. Parties could not appeal as to the facts but only on points of law.

Speedy and final resolutions to problems are important in takeovers. It is no good having a lengthy legal process or appeals and other similar delays. The panel was supposed to play an important role in facilitating this. However, insufficient consideration was given to the legislative changes needed to ensure that the panel would work as intended.

The very first application to come before the panel, the 1991 takeover bid by Titan Hills for Provision Data, highlighted substantive and procedural difficulties and resulted in five court actions, including one which went to the High Court. Rather than the panel dealing with the matter before it quickly, the Titan Hills case showed how events could become bogged down in front of the panel as legal representatives for the parties presented lengthy legalistic arguments. The matter was referred to the panel in May 1991, but no final decision was made until December 1991, seven months later. By that time, of course, the decision had been overtaken by events.

The parties finally agreed on a curative proposal, or settlement, involving a cash payment to uncommitted shareholders. However, the panel ruled that it had no power to consider matters that had occurred after the ASC's original referral for a declaration. The decision, of course, prejudiced the ability of the panel to reach a commercial judgment based on all relevant matters.

The time lag defeated one of the key policy reasons for the panel, namely, the ability—so vital in the fast-moving environment of takeovers, when delay may kill the purpose of action—to deal with the matters quickly. This has meant that unacceptable behaviour has largely been ignored by the ASC, as it has not referred matters to the panel. It does not mean that unacceptable behaviour has stopped. As the panel does not have the power to initiate a review, the ASC has been forced to attempt to act against unacceptable behaviour through civil proceedings.

The panel became bogged down in legal issues because of its power to make declarations and issue orders. As the Companies and Securities Bulletin commented, this ability to seriously affect individuals' rights and the issues of natural justice led to the involvement of a long list of barristers in the cases in a way that was not envisaged when the panel was mooted. The bill aims to streamline the operations of the panel. As part of this, point 3 of the new section 195 states:

SPEECH.PARA: The rules of natural justice do not apply in relation to an inquiry.
Instead, the section earlier on states:
Inquiries are to be conducted in accordance with the requirements of the regulations.
The government's most recent amendment adds that the regulations will `equate to the rules of natural justice.'

PARA.TAB: The Liberal Party recognises the need to improve the current situation. But it is entirely excessive for the government to attempt to vary natural justice to those appearing before the panel. It is worth while to remind ourselves of the role and importance of natural justice. Natural justice is a common law doctrine which courts apply when reviewing administrative or quasi-judicial decisions. It safeguards the right to procedural fairness of people affected by these decisions.

Natural justice involves two main principles: that a party whose interests are affected has a right to be heard, and that a decision maker should not be biased. Two further principles are often added: the need for probate evidence, and the reasons for decisions. The minister has stated:

SPEECH.PARA: Over zealous demands that procedural fairness be afforded may be a major impediment to an expeditious hearing as required by the (Corporations) Law.

Natural justice will be replaced with procedures, to be specified in the regulations accompanying the bill, to allow the panel to make decisions more quickly without disruption from parties and their legal advisers raising these common law principles. Acts of parliament can override the common law and it is possible for statutes to exclude natural justice. However, any legislative act that varies the application of the rules of natural justice should be very carefully examined.

PARA.TAB: Adherence to the rules of natural justice and corporate regulation has become a topical issue in Australia. The Senate Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs has been conducting an inquiry into the powers of officers of the Australian Securities Commission. In February this year, taking evidence in Brisbane, the committee heard a range of specific allegations against ASC investigators of harassment and denial of natural justice. The committee is yet to report on these matters but they have been given an airing in the media and carried on news reports. The panel is, of course, not one and the same as the ASC but it is established under the ASC Act. The ASC's predecessor, the National Companies and Securities Commission, was the subject of allegations of maverick behaviour. We do not want corporate cowboys but, as vigilante regulators are also undesirable, these concerns should be mentioned.

In the past, the panel has observed the rules of natural justice. Now the government has said that these are impeding prompt decision making by the panel and causing increased costs and delays. It is important to remember the yardstick for ensuring fairness that the rules of natural justice have provided in the past. Their variance should be a matter of serious consideration. Indeed, as this amendment is of considerable importance, it can even be debated whether such a measure should be contained in a bill supposed to consist of only a few `miscellaneous amendments'. If the fundamental rules of natural justice are to be all but eliminated, then it would appear only appropriate for their replacements to be contained in primary legislation rather than regulation.

The government is allowing us no opportunity to scrutinise the procedures that will be substituted for the principles of natural justice and will deny us the chance to debate or amend them. The Australian Institute of Company Directors has already claimed that the effective ban on legal representatives addressing the panel that this bill will impose should be lifted to allow lawyers the right to address the panel in matters which will directly affect the legal rights and interests of the parties called before it. The honourable member for Tangney has foreshadowed an amendment in this regard.

It has been pointed out that, although the panel considers market behaviour and standards rather than technical legal issues, a knowledge and appreciation of takeover regulation, often complex and legalistic itself, is needed for inquiries. This may not only require representation by lawyers but support from other experts such as accountants, stockbrokers and financial analysts. Given the range of orders that can be made by the panel, this measure must be considered unacceptable. Indeed, other aspects of the bill make a mockery of the government's intentions to streamline the operations of the panel. The panel will be superfluous if further appeals to courts—where matters may be dealt with by judicial officers with little experience in commerce, let alone takeovers—are still allowed. There can be no doubt that the rules of procedural justice should be detailed in the legislation. Persons appearing before the panel should be able to have another person to speak on their behalf and, if the panel is to have any real influence, appeals should be limited to matters of law and not the merits of decisions of the panel.

There is one further aspect of this bill which I wish to comment on—the now withdrawn amendments that would have given the government significant powers to alter the definitions of securities and futures contracts by regulation and without consultation. These provisions did not appear in the draft copy of the legislation released for industry and public review. The industry was understandably angry and concerned at the possibility of distortions in the regulation of over-the-counter and exchange traded derivatives. There is a need for flexibility to allow the ASX derivatives section and the Sydney Futures Exchange to conduct markets in new products and compete with overseas exchanges. Proposals for exchange traded products should not have adverse consequences for over-the-counter derivatives. The minister has said the proposals have been dropped to allow greater consultation and, as the Australian newspaper has noted, in the face of strong opposition from the Liberal Party and particularly the honourable member for Tangney.

We hear much of consultation from this government but all too often we actually see very little of it. I understand that when the decision was made to postpone these amendments, rather than issuing a release, the minister's staff phoned a few key players. I hope the consultation process will be somewhat more substantive and not carried out in a similar way. The over-the-counter derivatives market is now worth some $500 billion. I would hope that the government may be able to formulate proposals that are in line with the needs of the market and that will be compatible with the long-term reform recommendations currently under study by the Companies and Securities Advisory Committee. Of course, it would be entirely out of character for the government to pay heed to the other significant objection that the Liberal Party has raised and that I have discussed today. Then again, when we see some glimmer of light, I suppose we should still hold out some hope.

TALK.START.PARA: —Firstly, I thank all the members who participated in this debate. This is certainly one of the first full-blown debates in this new committee, and I think it has proceeded very well. I thank the members, particularly the members of the opposition, who are broadly in support of the provisions in this bill. There is disagreement on one point regarding the operation of some of the provisions regarding the panel, and I will address that in a little while. But, essentially, members have expressed support for the vast majority of items in the debate. I will touch on some of the items raised by members, particularly by the honourable member for Tangney (Mr Williams), who outlined a most cogent case on behalf of the opposition members. Other members of the opposition expanded on some of the points that the honourable member raised.

PARA.TAB: First, there was some criticism of the government's action in relation to the way it dealt with the definitions of `securities' and `futures contract'. Much has been made of the point that this particular provision was not included in the original bill for exposure and that it was subsequently withdrawn. I remind the committee what the circumstances were. The government was responding to an express request by the Australian Stock Exchange in relation to its desire to develop a new hybrid product between a security and a future. The Stock Exchange believes that this product will bring to the Australian market an innovation which is not seen in other markets around the world and which, potentially, will be of major commercial significance to this country. The time frame which the Stock Exchange was putting to the government at that time was that it wanted to place this product on the market on 1 July. It was in response to that particular request that the government went down this path.

I accept that it is not desirable that measures of this sort should not be subject to the full processes of consultation. However, there are occasions when one needs to be able to weigh the very great benefit gained through full consultation against other commercial and competing realities. This was one of those judgment decisions. The benefit which I believe, and which the Stock Exchange still argues, will flow to the Australian economy through the development of this product was one which, on balance, deserved the government's speedy response.

As events turned, the exchange advised that it would not be ready to proceed with this product until later in the year. We immediately took the opportunity to withdraw these particular provisions to allow for consultation. It was stated that there was no other consultation at all. That is simply not true. There was consultation with other players in this field, particularly the Sydney Futures Exchange. It certainly was not of the length which they would like, but if they have been putting out that they were not told at all, they are not being accurate. They certainly were told, and they were told about a month before the provision arose. I accept that that is not a long enough period, and that the detail supplied to them was not sufficient. But to say that they were not told at all until the thing ended up in the bill is simply not true.

Notwithstanding that, there are two issues which flow from it, although we should not spend too much time on it, since it is not actually part of the bill now. One issue concerns the over-the-counter trades. It is not the government's intention that these changes to the definitions should have impact on the over-the-counter trades. We will make clear, in the revised provisions which will come forward a little later in the year, that the over-the-counter trades are not affected by these proposals. That should satisfy one of the levels of concern.

The second level of concern is what appropriate regulations we put in. When we have one of these hybrid products, do we apply the chapter of the Corporations Law which relates to the securities market, do we apply the chapter of the law which applies to the futures market, or what combination of the two do we apply? That is the debate we need to have. It seems to me that it is a fairly fundamental debate, because this is not going to be the only time that products of this type will come forward. We are already seeing the Sydney Futures Exchange develop its own form of hybrid product. For instance, one can now trade in individual futures on individual shares. That is a new development which the futures market has put into the marketplace in recent times.

There are real issues here about how we adequately regulate this emerging market, which is neither fish nor fowl, and what combination of the law we use. Maybe there needs to be some sort of amalgam of the chapters. That will need serious debate. Whether we can have that sort of serious debate and that sort of outcome and still allow the Stock Exchange to develop its product is doubtful, and we might have to proceed on an interim basis. That will be less than satisfactory, but in terms of making sure that we are not disadvantaging our own markets that may be the path we have to go down.

The substance of the debate then turned on the operation of the panel. Talking a bit about the philosophy of it, the honourable member for Tangney again described this panel as being neither fish nor fowl: a combination including peer review, but not limited to that, in that it has some ability to make decisions which are binding—and, as such, an awkward creature. I suppose that is a fair comment, but a couple of points need to be made.

Firstly, if the Australian corporate sector wishes to develop its own systems of peer review which have nothing to do with the government, but may get some support from the government, we are very happy for it to do that. We are seeing some developments along this line. For instance, I raised in the House last week the development of the Stock Exchange incorporating within its listing rules certain ethical requirements and codes of practice in terms of the way in which company directors and companies operate, largely along the lines of the Cadbury code in the United Kingdom. That is a good example of corporate governance issues being taken up through a self-regulatory body such as the Stock Exchange. We are seeing various moves from the Australian Investment Managers Group and the genuine initiatives that the group pursues, and that again is something which the government very much encourages—as do I, personally.

But we have to face the fact that Australia has not had a very strong history of peer review, and we have tended to be a country which has approached corporate regulation through means of government legislative action. I do not know that that is particularly desirable in all cases, and as a general approach I am trying to move away from that and take the simplification approach. We have had considerable difficulties with the panel also going down that path, but the thrust of the panel is that it is not making legal determinations of whether something complies with the law. It is envisaged that generally something which would be brought before the panel would be a proposal which would be within the letter of the law, but not within its spirit.

The idea of the peer review is to concentrate on the sort of conduct which does no credit for the operation of the Australian markets but is not adequately accounted for by the actual strict operation of the law. Obviously, it does not matter how prescriptive the laws are. In fact, the more prescriptive the laws are, there are always going to be numerous cases which are not picked up although often they are within the intent of the law. The panel was to play that role—peer review by people experienced in corporate matters, business people making judgments and being involved in the review of corporate actions by other business people.

Unfortunately, the history of the panel has not been a happy one. The case that did go before it simply ended up in one of the largest legal cases that we have seen for some time. It certainly went nowhere near meeting the time frames prescribed for giving its decisions. It ended up in a High Court appeal against part of the panel's operation. There was obviously a need to review the procedures to see whether we could breathe life into this concept. I suppose at the end of the day, if these proposals do not succeed in the panel operating effectively, unfortunately I do not see much future for it. The thing has to operate on terms of good spirit and goodwill between the markets.

One of the things needed was some guidance as to the rules of natural justice which were applying; that is where a lot of the debate went on. The government's proposals here are aimed at specifying in some detail the procedures which the panel should be following, setting those out in a way which is clear both to the panel and to people and businesses which will be called before the panel. That is why we have gone down the path of setting these things out.

I note that the amendment which the government will propose concerning the application of the regulations which set out the procedures intended to equate to the rules of natural justice will not be opposed by the opposition. I gather from the honourable member for Tangney, however, that he is not terribly comfortable with that in totality. I do not know exactly why the opposition is supporting this, given the rather strong reservations expressed by the honourable member. Nonetheless, I am grateful that the opposition is supporting that amendment.

The next point where there is dispute, and there will be an amendment moved by the honourable member, concerns the exclusion of advisers. We are talking largely about lawyers. Some honourable members may include stockbrokers or other financial analysts there. That is possible but I think that in real terms we are talking about lawyers. This is excluding lawyers or any other advisers whatsoever not from giving people advice, which it is their proper right to have, or attending with them at panel deliberations, but from actually getting up on the hind legs and addressing the panel or conducting cross-examinations—in effect, taking over the proceedings.

As I read the provision—I have had this checked through the Office of General Counsel—there is nothing here precluding the panel, at its discretion, from allowing an adviser or a lawyer to get up and address it on a particular matter if the panel thinks that would be of benefit to the panel in resolving a particular item. What we are precluding is any absolute, unfettered right or entitlement of an adviser to address the panel. In that way we will focus on these proceedings being matters of peer review. Hopefully, we will have this panel discussing the acceptability of business conduct and not legal arguments or arguments of that sort. If we end up having to have legal arguments before the panel, it will have failed. It simply will have failed and we will not have achieved our end.

It really should be peer review, with business people speaking to business people and coming to a conclusion on the acceptability, in terms of the market practice and good corporate practice, of particular behaviour. If we get that outcome, then we will have a useful adjunct to our armoury. However, if we simply end up with a body which is turned into a pseudo-court in some way, then I think we will have largely defeated the purpose, and I would be dubious about its long-term future.

So let us make it clear that lawyers, or other advisers, will certainly be in the room sitting next to their clients. They will be able to advise them. They will be able to give whatever advice is necessary in terms of the presentation of written material. If I am right—and, as I said, I have had it confirmed through the Office of General Counsel—the panel itself is by no means precluded by these provisions from asking an adviser to clarify a particular point, if the panel believes that is useful, but we are stopping the automatic right of someone to get up and make representations. So, in my mind, this is a reasonable conclusion and should be supported for those reasons. No doubt we will talk about it a bit later, but the government will not be supporting that particular amendment.

There were a few other points which the honourable member raised. He asked about the changes regarding charges, in that they are to be regulated under the financial institutions legislation. He was worried that this would worsen the fragmentation of personal property security registration in Australia. I have some sympathy for that view, I have to say. However, this is a very strong point of view which was put by the states and, given the cooperative nature of our federalism, the Commonwealth conceded that point. However, a Law Reform Commission report on personal property securities is now before the Standing Committee of Attorneys-General. It may be that through consideration of that report we will look again at this issue and the states might reconsider their view.

The honourable member also asked a practical question as to whether there will be a transfer of charges over financial institution property registered under the Corporations Law to state registers. I am advised on that point that the Australian Securities Commission and the Australian Financial Institutions Commission are discussing the administrative arrangements in relation to the changes included in this bill. Both of those organisations understand the desirability of reaching an arrangement whereby those people searching a register of charges do have a comprehensive register. This is something which they are discussing and, hopefully, we can come to an arrangement which will accommodate that.

In conclusion, I thank honourable members for their support. It is unfortunate that we do not have total agreement on every provision in this bill. There is one point of disagreement, but on the whole I think these are useful reforms in a variety of areas. I thank members for their contributions.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time.
Clauses 1 to 17—by leave—taken together, and agreed to.
Schedules 1 to 3—by leave—taken together, and agreed to.
Schedule 4.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Williams Mr D.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: Schedule 4, page 35, omit item 19, substitute the following item:

PARA.TAB: Omit the subsection, substitute:

SPEECH.PARA: `(4) A person who appears at an inquiry is entitled to have another person present to assist the person and a person who so assists is entitled to address the Panel.'.".

This raises the issue referred to by the Attorney-General (Mr Lavarch) in his reply, and that is the question of the entitlement of a person appearing at an inquiry before the Corporations and Securities Panel to have a representative, not only assisting, but actually addressing the panel.

PARA.TAB: As formulated in the bill, subsection 194(4) provides for the entitlement of a person who appears to have another person present to assist. It then goes on to say that the person who so assists is not entitled to address the panel. It seems to me that, irrespective of the merits of the principle of excluding that person from addressing the panel in that way, it gets picked up by the wrong handle. A person who so assists would not, in any forum, normally have a right, or an entitlement—using the language of the bill—to address the panel but would only have a right of audience. The entitlement to address would be as agent of the person who appears at the inquiry. It may be a small point but, since the Attorney-General has suggested that it does not exclude the granting of leave by the panel to a person in a particular case, it may be something that is worth addressing.

For the reasons that I offered in my speech in the second reading debate, we believe that it is inappropriate, in a situation where a body such as this panel has power to affect the rights and duties of persons, that the right of an agent to address as well as otherwise assist should be excluded. Without elaborating on it any further, that is the reason we moved this amendment.

TALK.START.PARA: —As I indicated before, the government unfortunately cannot agree to this amendment—I am not quite certain how the procedure goes from here—essentially for the same reasons which I outlined in my reply. Obviously, we see a considerable role for advisers to people who would have business before the panel. There is no suggestion that people should not be able to have recourse to advice they deem appropriate—legal advice, financial business advice and assistance in the preparation of any material which will be presented before the panel.

PARA.TAB: Given that the thrust of a lot of the reforms we have here are to concentrate on written submissions before the panel rather than on oral hearings, and given that we hope the panel will be hearing matters of a business and market conduct nature rather than matters of a technical or legal nature—and there is the bit of experience which occurred during the Titan Hills matter and the way that some of the proceedings of the Trade Practices Commission operate with similar provisions—the government has concluded that there should be some restrictions on the entitlement, or right, to appear. I take the honourable member's point about the expression there; we might have a look at that. At this point the government cannot agree to this amendment.
Question unresolved.

TALK.START.PARA: —This amendment having been moved and not having been unanimously agreed to, I ask that the motion for the amendment be recorded in the report to the House as a matter on which there has not been agreement.

PARA.TAB: The DEPUTY SPEAKER (Mr Nehl)—Could we try to make it quite clear in the event of the vote being called in this chamber that, if there is one disputed call—in other words, were you to have said, `No, the ayes have it—

TALK.START.PARA: —I think both sides of the House have got it the wrong way around.
—Are you actually saying the ayes have it?
—We are saying the ayes have it; the government is saying that the noes have it.
—The question is that the amendment be agreed to. Those of that opinion say aye; to the contrary, no. I think the noes have it.
—In that event, I request that our dissent be recorded.

—As the question is unresolved, in accordance with standing order 276, the question will be included in the committee's report on the bill to the House. It might be easier on future occasions if we follow the same procedure that occurs in the other chamber: if there is disagreement, we just say the ayes have it or the noes have it or whatever, and then it will be much simpler than having to make requests. That having been resolved, I understand that the government has an additional amendment under schedule 4.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lavarch The Hon M.H.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is good to be part of history, the first time that a matter has to be referred back to the main chamber. I do not think this particular amendment will have the same effect. I move:

SPEECH.PARA: Schedule 4, page 35, item 20, proposed subsection 195(3), omit the proposed subsection, substitute the following subsection:

PARA.TAB: "`(3) It is intended that this Division and the regulations will set out procedural requirements that equate to the rules of natural justice.'.".

SPEECH.PARA: This particular amendment, as we have canvassed before, deals with the application of the rules of natural justice to the proceedings of the panel. The provision which appeared in the bill made the bland statement that the rules of natural justice should not apply—or do not apply. Naturally enough, the opposition took some exception to that particular provision and, through a process of discussion with the office of Senator Vanstone, the shadow Attorney-General, I understand agreement has been reached on the wording of this amendment.

PARA.TAB: The intention of the provision—hopefully, made clearer by the amendment—is not that there not be the application of natural justice to the way this panel operates. The basic rules of natural justice are that people have the right to be heard and to comment on adverse material before a particular body and that people are entitled to an unbiased adjudicator in such matters.

Beyond that, courts have added to or detracted from the rules of natural justice. It is a bit of a moveable feast in a sense, and I noted with some interest the recent decision of the Federal Court in the case of Teoh on what it deemed to be appropriate in the rules of natural justice in an immigration case. It is an area which is of some interest.

In this particular case, through the regulations we are attempting to set out in some detail the procedures which should be followed by the panel and by people who have business before the panel. The procedures in the regulations set out a scheme which reasonably protects people's rights and outlines the fair operation of the panel and the way those proceedings should go ahead. It would be unfortunate if the panel were to then be subjected to court challenge in terms of the way it operates in following these procedures. Such a challenge is, of course, possible but, in such an event, the provision in this amendment is showing that the legislature's intention is that the procedures set out in the regulations equate to the rules of natural justice, and maybe that will be something which a court, if there were such a challenge, would take into account.

TALK.START.PARA: —As I have previously indicated, it is not the intention of the coalition to oppose this motion but, as I have also indicated, I have some uneasiness personally with it. The Attorney-General (Mr Lavarch) has sought to justify the terms. I think I should explain in a bit more detail the reason for my uneasiness. The provision in the bill effectively excludes natural justice from the proceedings of the panel. That would mean that, if a challenge to the procedure of the panel were taken to a court, the court would not have regard to decisions on procedural fairness in order to determine whether the procedure was in fact fair.

PARA.TAB: The amendment says, in effect, that what is set out in the act and the regulations is the equivalent of natural justice. In other words, the procedure is the statement of the procedural fairness that will apply in proceedings before the panel. If one contemplates what is going to happen when the procedure before the panel is subject to a challenge before a court, the effect seems to me to be almost identical to the exclusion of natural justice. What it is doing is saying that what we have set out as the procedure in the act and the regulations is natural justice; and if those procedural rules do not cover the situation, the court is effectively excluded from going to background rules or background precedent in order to determine what is procedurally fair in this uncontemplated situation. So it does not seem to me to change matters very much.

I do not have such confidence in the government or the Attorney-General's Department or in the Office of Parliamentary Counsel as to make the assumption that all the procedures that will be required to be employed before the panel have been dealt with in the act or the regulations. It seems to me that the panel is going to be in a rather difficult situation, having been told that this is the limit of procedural rules it is allowed to operate under and nothing else will be effective.

It means, perhaps, that there will be a second level of procedural rule. It will not be recognised by a court but it will have to be applicable. I think it raises complexities that need not be there. While I accept that the panel is meant to operate informally and summarily and deal with matters relatively quickly and procedural fairness ought not to be a problem, there will inevitably be situations, if the panel does succeed in attracting business to itself, where there will be a need to resolve what procedure is to be adopted. It seems to me that the government would have nothing to lose by saying, `These are the rules' and otherwise leaving the ordinary rules of procedural fairness to apply.
Amendment agreed to.
Schedule, as amended, agreed to.
Schedules 5 to 7—by leave—taken together, and agreed to.
Schedule 8.
