TALKER.NAME: Mr LINDSAY
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Industry, Science and Technology)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That the bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.PARA: The Customs Tariff Amendment Bill 1994, which is now before the House, contains a number of amendments to the Customs Tariff Act 1987. Some of the amendments have already been introduced as customs tariff proposals. I will briefly outline the changes of substance.

PARA.TAB: Schedule 3 is operative from 1 September 1993. It designates Eritrea as a developing country under the Australian system of tariff preferences. This follows Australia's formal recognition of Eritrea as an independent country on 4 May 1993. Prior to that date, Eritrea was considered to be part of Ethiopia. This action will allow imports of Eritrean origin to enter Australia at concessional rates of duty.

Further amendments contained in this schedule give effect to the government's decision, as announced in the 1993-94 federal budget, to increase the customs duty on aviation gasoline and aviation kerosene by 0.264c per litre. These changes will enable the Civil Aviation Authority to recover part of the cost of aviation safety regulation from the industry. The balance of the industry's contribution will be phased in over the next two years. There is a complementary change contained in section 6 of this bill which inserts the tariff subheading for aviation kerosene in the table to section 26(1) of the principal act. As a result, consumer price index increases will be applied to the rate of duty for this product.

Schedule 4 of the bill will operate from 14 days after the bill receives royal assent and creates item 63 in schedule 4 to the principal act. Reference materials are materials of accurately known composition which are used as the standard against which like materials, processes and apparatus are calibrated. Access to reference materials at world prices, without the added impost of duty, is important if Australian industry is to be internationally competitive. Most of the analytical standards used in Australia for a range of testing purposes are not produced locally and must be imported. Concessional entry can be best delivered through a new policy item. This approach has industry support.

In its 1991 Building a Better Australia statement, the government announced that, commencing on 1 July 1992, it would phase out the bounty payable on the production of certain textile yarn over the following three years. In its stead, the government will introduce from 1 July 1995 a five per cent tariff duty on the subject yarn. The amendments contained in schedule 5 put in place the new tariff rate.

Other changes are of an administrative nature and have no duty implications. Summaries of the amendments contained in this bill have been prepared and are being circulated for the information of honourable members. I commend the bill to the Main Committee.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sharp Mr J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —On behalf of the coalition, I am representing the responsible shadow minister. He cannot be here today, so I will read some of the advice he has given me, and then move to the matters that are of particular concern to me.

PARA.TAB: This bill replaces the current bounty on textiles, clothing and footwear products with a five per cent tariff. Given that the five per cent tariff is to be applied to all imports, the Australian system of tariff preferences, which gives preferential tariff treatment to developing countries, does not apply in this case. This measure is one of a number of changes arising from the 1990 review of the textile, clothing and footwear plan. The changes to be phased in by 1995 include: the abolition of TCF quotas by 1993; the phase-down of tariffs to 25 per cent by the year 2000; extra funding for the industry's development strategy; the introduction of an imports credit scheme; and the abolition of bounties on 1 July 1995. They are replaced with a five per cent tariff.

The replacement of bounty with a tariff will continue the phased reduction of protection for the industry. For example, a bounty of 20 per cent and based on 75 per cent value added is equivalent to a 15 per cent tariff. This measure has the support of industry and is a central plank in the TCF plan to which industry has been working. Moreover, it is upon this plan that the industry has modelled its restructuring and made investment decisions. The TCF industry has invested some $630 million over the past three years. Given this and the importance of fostering business confidence and industry stability, the coalition will not oppose the amendment.

A number of minor administrative amendments are also proposed in this bill, including: the removal of redundant quota provisions from the principal act; the import of reference material free of duty; the consolidation of tariff headings; and the recognition of Eritrea as a developing country and its inclusion in the developing country tariff preference scheme.

As we also heard from the Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Industry, Science and Technology (Mr Lindsay), the Customs Tariff Amendment Bill 1994, like the Excise Tariff Amendment Bill that we debated just over a month ago, contains measures to increase the duty on aviation gasoline and aviation kerosene by 0.264c per litre and to make this subject to consumer price index increases for the purpose of enabling the Civil Aviation Authority to recover part of the cost of aviation safety regulation from the aviation industry.

That would be all well and good if it did not beg a very central question: what air safety regulation? I spoke during debate on the Excise Tariff Amendment Bill of my concern about the CAA and its administration of air safety regulation, a concern that initially sprang from the fact that five people from my electorate died, along with the pilot and co-pilot, in a tragic Monarch airline crash at Young one year ago this coming Saturday.

I have been appalled to learn that the CAA was well aware that the airline in question, Monarch Air, was a shonky operator of the first order, that CAA airworthiness inspectors had recommended its grounding less than two months before the crash, and that CAA had identified Monarch as a major problem as early as November 1991 but had done next to nothing about ensuring that an operator which was clearly a threat to the safety of the travelling public was stopped from operating.

Let me state at the outset that most regional airlines operate in an exemplary manner. They carry out proper maintenance programs, they have proper flying operations and they are responsible people. But as with so much of life, there are a few rotten apples in the barrel. It is to these people that I address my remarks. Since my last speech, many people have provided me with further information that confirms beyond doubt that air safety regulation is in very dire straits in this country.

Throughout the industry, the story was consistent: from an aircraft mechanic who complained of the pressure brought to bear on him to release aircraft that in fact needed further maintenance, to people inside the CAA itself who are distressed that their very purpose and their mission statements are being made a mockery.

The inescapable conclusion is that the CAA has absolutely fallen victim to commercial priorities and has virtually abandoned the primacy of its air safety regulatory role as set out in the act. With the formation of the CAA, the self-insurance cover of the Commonwealth was lost, and the CAA was obliged to take out its own insurance. It carries a series of policies for a variety of liabilities through brokers. Basic in that cover is the constraint placed on the CAA by its insurers not to admit fault or to face a voiding of its policy as their consequence. This means that it is simply not possible for the CAA to admit fault. Therefore, the CAA has a very real problem from the outset in acknowledging that there is error and setting it to rights.

Therefore, the commercial needs of the relationship with the insurers take precedence over the need for regulation of air safety and the need to be subject to continuing scrutiny and self-correction, with the result that the CAA has developed a tendency to cover up and to paper over the cracks in order to protect its insurance arrangements. When those cracks are related to the safety of the travelling public, that is simply not to be tolerated.

Following my revelation of its manifest shortcomings in dealing with Monarch, rather than addressing the problem, CAA has gone into damage control mode—firstly, by seeking to deny that the problem exists, but also by embarking on witch-hunts in an effort to discover the source of the leaks which enable the truth about its blunders with Monarch to see the light of day at all. To put it simply, the CAA has closed ranks.

The undeniable truth is that there is a systemic disease in the CAA. What I have learned about its operations since my speech a month ago leads me to conclude that the CAA has become some sort of flying boys club where favours are traded and the mates system flourishes, leading to a very serious form of corruption which undermines the very principles which would enable regulation without fear or favour.

There is a case that has all the attributes of a Pink Panther movie set at Fawlty Towers about it and that is shortly to see some alleged offenders against the civil aviation regulations brought before the court, but only because the CAA spectacularly bungled its efforts to keep its mates out of court. Because the case is shortly to come before the court, and it is therefore sub judice, I will not refer to the protagonists by name, or in any way identify them. Let me call them Basil Fawlty and Peter Sellers. What matters in the story is the CAA's extraordinary behaviour in seeking to prevent the prosecution of the case at all.

At a regional aero club, Basil Fawlty was an approved test officer, which means that he was delegated by the CAA to test applicants for pilot's licences and endorsements. In the case of Peter Sellers' application for a pilot's licence, some suspicion arose about the conduct of this delegation, because, on the day when Mr Sellers' flying test was supposed to have taken place, Mr Fawlty, the approved test officer, was not even at the airport, let alone present at the test. A CAA investigating officer prepared the briefs, recommending—

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member for Hume has already indicated that he is aware that this question is sub judice. I know he is not using names, but he is recounting circumstances which could be construed as possibly having some influence on the outcome of the case. I invite him to be very careful in what he says.

—Thank you very much, Mr Deputy Speaker. I have sought advice on the manner in which I should address this matter in the Main Committee and, to the best of my ability, I am following the advice. Thank you for the caution.

PARA.TAB: A CAA investigating officer prepared briefs recommending that action be taken against both Mr Fawlty and the applicant, Mr Sellers, who is a man of some considerable influence in this regional centre. The regional flight operations manager, however, instead of acting on the recommendation of the investigating officer, simply made a telephone call to Mr Sellers, who happened to be a mate of his.

There it might have rested as just another CAA cover-up, except that the word had spread on the grapevine. The head of flight operations in Canberra, Maurie Basten, got to hear of it, and mistakenly concluded that the brief prepared by the investigating officer had been passed to the state prosecutor's office. Mr Basten, who fits the bill for Manuel in the theme, then wrote to state prosecuting officers, seeking to have that office drop the prosecution. Mr Basten did not realise—

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! I am sorry, you did mention a name at that stage. You may have taken legal advice, and I am certainly no arbiter of legal advice, but I again advise you to be very cautious.

—Thank you, Mr Deputy Speaker. The person whose name I have mentioned is not involved in the court case in any way whatsoever. For that reason, I feel it can be mentioned in appropriate circumstances here in the chamber, recognising that the names of those people who are involved in the court case have not been mentioned. The state in which the incident is alleged to have occurred has not been mentioned. No reference to a particular person, day, date or anything has been made in this chamber, and will not be made in this chamber.
—Thank you for that. I still invite you to be very careful.

—Thank you. What Mr Basten did not realise was that this was the first that the state prosecutor's office had heard of the matter. Its interest was aroused, however, and the office requested the files. Unfortunately, he had inadvertently let the cat out of the bag. The state prosecutor's office, on assessing the files, passed the case over to federal DPP authorities, with the result that the case is—as I mentioned before—to be brought before the court within some few days.

PARA.TAB: I will leave the determination of the merits of case against Mr Fawlty and Mr Sellers to the legal system. But just what did Mr Basten, the CAA officer at the centre of responsibility for air safety regulation, think he was doing in seeking to prevent the prosecution taking place? That interference echoes another case that I referred to last month in this place, where a senior CAA officer also attempted to have a case withdrawn from prosecution.

The CAA's job is to protect the travelling public from danger; it is not to protect aviation operators from the processes of the law. Unfortunately, this matey protectionism is not confined to flying operators, either. Winrye, a maintenance firm at Bankstown, has been a persistent offender against civil aviation regulations and requirements. Over the past two years, a series of noncompliance notices issued for breaches of regulations and procedures led to a `show cause' letter being sent to the owner demanding that the owner show cause why his certificate to operate should not be varied or cancelled. This owner, described as a maverick by many within the industry, did not even reply to this letter, which is an offence in itself.

Despite this, the CAA did nothing and left the firm free to continue operating. Two months ago, a further series of noncompliance notices led to another `show cause' letter. The offences included performing work that the firm was not qualified to do, such as testing torque on engines, and signing for work it was not licensed to do, such as instrument electrical work. The owner's response to that letter was unsatisfactory. It did not explain or absolve the noncompliance record.

PARA.TAB: The point I would make—and I was surprised that the honourable member for Maribyrnong did not make it in his point of order—is that, while the chair has been particularly indulgent to the honourable member for Hume because of his specific interest in this particular area, I feel bound to remind him and other speakers in this debate that this is the Customs Tariff Amendment Bill. It imposes a levy on aviation fuel. The increase has been announced to enable the Civil Aviation Authority to recover part of the costs of aviation safety. The honourable member for Hume is, to a very large extent, talking about aviation safety in the context of the money to pay for it, but I do invite him to be a little more direct to the subject matter of the bill.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will just make the point that the matters that I am now referring to, and will refer to from this point forward in my speech, are not before any court; no charges have been laid. Therefore, the issue of sub judice for the rest of the speech does not apply. It could be argued that matters that I referred to earlier could be. PARA.TAB: I will just go on from where I was. At this point, a senior officer of the CAA reportedly interfered in order to prevent the cancellation of the licence. Other CAA officers at the site were so incensed at this abuse that they have gone over that officer's head to bring the matter

SPEECH.PARA: to head office in Canberra. To this date, however, no action has been taken against the firm—two months later. The proprietor is also, interestingly enough, deeply involved in war birds. Again, the flying mates syndrome can be seen here.

PARA.TAB: The flying mates syndrome was strongly in evidence in Adelaide in the issue of licences for aircraft maintenance engineers to a series of former air force engineers who did not hold appropriate qualifications. The issue of these licences, by a CAA licensing officer who had been an air force colleague of the applicants, came to the attention of the CAA's Wagga Wagga district office when renewal of one was sought there. The airworthiness inspector at Wagga Wagga district office described the licence issues as `fraudulent' and made a series of recommendations for corrective action. While senior officers agreed with that inspector that the licences were issued without proper qualifications, no action was taken.

The situation is a serious one and puts in doubt a number of licences issued since 1991 by the CAA officer in question and, possibly, by others. The issue of these licences has been described as using the `freebie in the breakfast cereal box' method. The fact that the method involves former Australian Defence Force personnel, whose experience in aviation and whose responsibilities do not parallel those of the licensed aircraft maintenance engineer, makes that practice dangerous. That so many are apparently former colleagues of the licensing officer or officers makes it potentially corrupt. Only engineers meeting the very high standards specified in the civil aviation regulations should be entrusted with the responsibilities of licensed aircraft maintenance engineers, which directly affect the standards of aviation safety. Any watering down of these standards is not to be tolerated. When these occur as a product of a mateship code, the situation is not only dangerous but severely out of control, and threatens the lives of countless thousands of people each week.

The CAA is repeatedly displaying symptoms of an organisation that is out of control and that has completely lost its way. The CAA report in August last year on Singleton Air Services, trading as Yanda Airlines, identified a number of serious deficiencies in various aspects of that company's operation. The report found that the chief pilot had failed to ensure that company pilots complied with the required procedures—as indeed he himself had failed to do; that proper certification of both scheduled and unscheduled maintenance was not undertaken; and that those responsible had not ensured that maintenance was carried out when required. It listed failure to observe defect recording, to apply the minimum equipment list and in the maintenance control manual.

The report is a litany of violations, which led the senior airworthiness inspector to recommend that immediate action be taken against the air operator's certificate. That recommendation was not acted upon, and an action plan was adopted for the operator to be given another chance. Subsequent ramp checks still reflected shortcomings in Yanda's fulfilment of requirements. It is relevant that the responsible district airworthiness manager, in a CAA internal electronic memorandum, had said:

SPEECH.PARA: I have no doubt that the Governing Director of the company is well aware of the way the operation is conducted and doubt that any sustained improvement will occur unless we are prepared to cancel the operator's RPT AOC.

That is a regular public transport air operators certificate. But the CAA has made it clear that cancelling a regular public transport air operators certificate is just what it is not prepared to do. The operators have become the CAA's customers, and the customer, in the end, is always right. Even when the need for the strongest action is recognised within the CAA, the commercial culture takes over and regulatory inertia sets in. It is the inertia in the regulatory function that has become the greatest problem of the CAA and it is a direct result of confusion over the CAA's fundamental purpose.

PARA.TAB: While the government is determined to reduce its contribution to the funding of regulation, it is still drawing profit revenue from the CAA, as Dick Smith has pointed out in a letter to the Director of Aviation Safety Standards and Regulation which was reported in the Canberra Times earlier this week. In fact, $28 million in company tax was paid, and $15.2 million in dividend was paid to the federal government.

Of the CAA's all-up cost for the safety function of $60 million, the federal government contributes a maximum of $22.8 million from 1 July 1995—considerably less than its earnings from the authority. The federal government therefore profits from the regulation of the CAA to the tune of $20.4 million annually. This is, in my view, the equivalent of asking the police force to pay a dividend to the government. Mr Smith has argued that if the CAA and the government were in fact giving primacy to safety over commercial considerations, then a greater part of its earnings would be dedicated to its safety regulatory functions.

There is an even greater problem, however, because regulation and commercial considerations are as oil and water. It is the confusion of the two that has led to the current collapse of priorities in the CAA and to the virtual abandonment of regulatory rigour. The inertia is manifest when one considers the fate that has met the various recommendations regarding surveillance and audit in the organisation. The Division of Air Safety Standards and Regulation identified surveillance to the Terrell report in 1993 as a priority area. At point 2.11 the report states:

SPEECH.PARA: There is a need to have a clearer picture of the effectiveness and adequacy of the surveillance undertaken by the Division. There is no ready means of obtaining a national analysis of the state of health of the industry. The lack of central control and guidance on implementation and surveillance matters was widely seen as a major deficiency.

It still is. It was a major problem in the Monarch case, it continues as a major problem in dealing with cases such as Yanda, and it has allowed cowboys to continue to operate with virtual impunity. At point 5 in the Terrell report, the division gave this assurance:

Surveillance plan to bring together in a coherent strategy the surveillance and auditing that will be undertaken in various sectors of the industry, the reporting and follow-up actions, including enforcement policies. The plan will be based on work already well advanced in the Division and will detail the process for national collection and analysis of data to be used to manage the surveillance program and to report to the CEO and Board. As currently planned, the new surveillance system will need to be implemented in July 1993.

Yet that surveillance system is still not in place today, almost one year after the division identified the urgent need. The progress on the surveillance system has become bogged down and, ironically, the computerised system that was previously in place has been abandoned. Despite repeated acknowledgments that a surveillance system is vital, it is still in limbo. It is obvious that the CAA needs drastic remedial surgery; this cannot wait. The Monarch crash was a tragic warning of what can happen.

PARA.TAB: The purpose of my contributions today, a month ago and in the future is to show that Monarch was not a `one-off': it is the tip of the iceberg. There are to this day, courtesy of the CAA, other airlines which flagrantly disregard good commercial practices, good maintenance procedures and good flying procedures, and which every day risk the lives of Australians who unwittingly buy tickets on their airlines.

It is beholden on us, as those people's representatives, to do everything in our power to ensure that aviation safety is maintained by acting immediately to cut out the rot that has taken over the Commonwealth's regulator, or policeman, of aviation, the CAA. There is no gain to be had for the government in protecting the CAA. The problem is so obvious and the interest so great that the problem simply will not go away. Every day that we delay the reform of the CAA is another day that we run the risk of one of the cowboy outfits driving a plane full of passengers into the side of a hill, as Monarch managed to do to my constituents one year ago this Saturday.

Please, let us not delay solving the problems, whether they relate to insurance arrangements, the CAA or some of the airline operators themselves. The shortcomings are so glaring that it would be abandoning our basic role as parliamentarians to allow the situation to continue one day longer than it has to. The government must initiate an investigation into the CAA now, with the specific task of reform of the organisation. Otherwise, we will all be back here in a year's time with an even worse problem and still more Australians having paid the ultimate price for the failure to get aviation safety regulation right, just as my constituents did a year ago this Saturday.
Mr Deputy Speaker, I seek leave to table documents confirming the comments that I have made about Yanda Airlines and the maintenance licences issued to the operators in Adelaide.
Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Customs Tariff Amendment Bill 1994 is a bill that is not opposed by the opposition. There are three purposes to it: the change in the rate of duty for the imports of textile yarns; goods from Eritrea being given a concessional tariff basis; and the increase in the rate of duty on aviation fuels. It is on that latter point that I would like to spend just one or two minutes in this debate, because this particular piece of legislation is parallel to another bill that went through the House about a month ago, the Excise Tariff Amendment Bill. The basis of this bill was to be able to provide the Civil Aviation Authority with 50 per cent of the cost recovery process in providing safety services. May I just say that the honourable member who has just resumed his seat, the honourable member for Hume (Mr Sharp), did flag a number of points that I was going to raise. Today I will not go through that and I will not go through some of the things that I think must ultimately be said, in light of your earlier rulings, Mr Deputy Speaker, on the sub judice provisions.

PARA.TAB: There is abroad a very real concern about what is happening with the CAA and what is happening in terms of the regulation and the provision of safety services in Australia. The honourable member for Hume raised a most salient point indeed, that is, just where we go in the provision of safety services, how far we take the cost recovery process, and whether we are getting to a stage where we are now going beyond the cost recovery process in those provisions. The point is whether there should not be a complete relook at the way we do administer aviation safety.

I think it is true that people on my side of the Main Committee generally supported the concept of a user-pays principle for the CAA, but obviously the program that had been devised in New Zealand and, to an extent, in the United States has also had some very great difficulties, and those countries are now reviewing the situation as to whether or not that full cost recovery should be applied.

The analogy that was drawn a little bit earlier with what we do in terms of the police force was, I think, a fairly good analogy to make. The reality is that the safety division, in the administration of safety, is really a police force from the Civil Aviation Authority. If we are going to have the proper surveillance and the proper maintenance of our safety provisions in Australia, maybe we should relook at the way we provide those services. I hope that the government takes up the suggestion of a complete review of the CAA. As I said earlier, there is no doubt at all that there are some very real concerns about what is going on and a great deal of dissatisfaction with the whole area of cost recovery.

The application of the new costs on avtur and avgas are only a very small part of the equation. If we look at what is happening overseas now, in terms of the CAA and the services that it can provide, we see that there are some examples of where it can make some money and where it can hive off some of its services, which would allow it to become very much a small regulatory body that sets up the standards; and we can still apply some of that cost recovery to that process.

One of the things that is being examined at the moment, particularly in the United States and now in the United Kingdom, is the privatisation of the provision of air traffic control services. There has indeed been some success there. If the government is worried about some of these costs, that is one area that could well be examined. Before air traffic controllers around Australia go into a state of seizure, let me say that one of the things that has worked overseas and has really got some attraction in Australia is the possibility that those air traffic controllers can very much become part of the companies that provide those air traffic services. The evidence that we have from overseas is that, when that happens, we not only get a much more efficient system of air traffic control but, because there is some sense of profit motive within the process, people become much more interested in the operations of air traffic control, and the nature of air traffic control is improved considerably.

I suggest that the government, like its counterparts in New Zealand, the United States and the UK, should examine the possibility of that particular process. Various estimates have been made as to what may happen if that were brought in, and the suggestion is that we may be able to see the throughput of aircraft quite safely in a place like Sydney, where there are and will continue to be—

TAB.EMPHASIS: A division having been called in the House of Representatives—

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! As a division has been called for in the House, the proceedings of the Main Committee are suspended. Proceedings will recommence when the chair is resumed. The honourable member for Fadden will have leave to continue his remarks then.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy Speaker, prior to the interruption I was talking about the real need for the government to look at the reorganisation of the Civil Aviation Authority. I was talking about some of the options that it may have in terms of reducing costs and increasing efficiencies in light of aspects of the Customs Tariffs Amendment Bill, which is all about providing 50 per cent of the cost of the safety contract. I was talking about the option of hiving off some of the present requirements of the Civil Aviation Authority to allow it to become a very small, lean, mean and efficient organisation that really sets up the policy and the administration of aviation in Australia, getting itself out of some of those areas which it need not be in and which could be provided more efficiently by private enterprise.

PARA.TAB: I think, though, at the end of the day the real decision that the government has got to make is: what is going to be the nature of safety administration within the Civil Aviation Authority? It would seem to me that, if the government is serious about providing the most efficient and cost-effective administration of aviation in Australia, one of the options that it should look at is having the CAA as a small regulatory body quite separate from that—a special division that would administer the safety aspects of aviation and one that was divorced from the commercial pressures.

My colleague the honourable member for Hume raised in his speech some of the problems that those commercial pressures bring. I think there is a real difficulty within the organisation as it stands at the moment. The feeling is that it must look after the requirements of commercial operators and that perhaps that can take some priority over the provision of the safety standards. I think that in any review we should look at having the safety division stand alone. That would have to be funded directly from the public purse if we were going to get over some of the difficulties that we have got here at the moment.

The aviation industry always harks back to the days of Sir Donald Anderson. It was during that period that Australia probably led the world in the provision of aviation services; we had a tremendous reputation. The commercial reality is that those days have passed but there is still an opportunity for Australia to have the best aviation services in the world. I think that it would be a relatively easy thing to bring about. I would hope that, while the controversy still rages about how the funding of safety administration in Australia is going to be paid for, the government would grasp the nettle and make sure that it was a thorough examination. I would hope that it would look very closely indeed at being able to separate those particular divisions and would make sure that the safety administration stood alone as a completely independent body.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Abbott Mr A.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to support the Customs Tariff Amendment Bill. I endorse the comments of previous speakers, particularly those of the honourable member for Fadden (Mr Jull) and the honourable member for Hume (Mr Sharp), on the need for much better standards of aviation safety and for a sharpening up of the act of the Civil Aviation Authority.

PARA.TAB: I note in particular the provisions of this bill giving Eritrea status as a developing country. I applaud the government's move in this direction because the people of Eritrea have suffered enormously over many years now. They were being persecuted for a long time by the Ethiopian government. Tens of thousands of them were killed in war. Probably hundreds of thousands of them died of starvation. It is only right and fitting that the Australian people should in some way recognise them and in some way help them by giving them special status in terms of our tariff regime.

I do not normally agree with my great protagonist in the republican debate, Tom Keneally, but certainly I very much support and admire the work that Tom Keneally has done to publicise the plight of the people of Eritrea and to help them in their various difficulties. The fact that this bill applies the system of tariff preferences in respect of Eritrea provides me with the opportunity to make a few comments about the tariff issue. I do not intend to trespass on the chamber's time for any great period but it is important, in the light of comments that the government members keep making about this whole tariff question, to touch on it.

Tariffs have a long history in Australia. The federation movement itself dealt with this problem. I suppose that tariffs have been seen in the Australian context as a way of building up infant industries and helping them come to maturity. The problem with tariffs in this country has sometimes been that these industries have moved from infancy to senility without ever passing through a period of maturity and development. Notwithstanding that, tariffs do exercise a fascination for the general public. In some polling in the United States recently, US citizens were asked to choose between, on the one hand, their country being twice as rich as it is now and the Japanese being twice as rich again, and, on the other hand, their country being no richer than it is now and the Japanese being no richer, so the relativities were preserved. They all chose to preserve the relativities rather than to go for absolute wealth increases if it meant that the relativities changed. So there is a great hold by tariffs on the popular psyche.

Many people regard this whole question as a bit like the injunction to love one's enemies. In an ideal world we would do it but in the real world it is very hard to do. Nevertheless, it is important that we continue to pursue a policy of tariff reform. Notwithstanding all these arguments in favour of industry protection, tariffs in the Australian context have not been very successful. For instance, in the clothing industry between 1971 and 1991, even though the effective rate of protection almost doubled, the actual employment almost halved. In the footwear manufacturing industry between 1971 and 1991, even though the effective rate of protection almost quadrupled, actual employment declined by a factor of four.

Some of these industries which historically have been heavily protected, such as TCF and motor vehicles, even though in the last few years the rate of protection has again begun to decline, have started to develop once more. My colleague the honourable member for Hume pointed out that the TCF industry has invested $600 million over the last three years, even though the effective rate of protection has begun to decline.
Tariffs are burdensome, they are cumbersome, they are difficult to comply with, and they involve very heavy bureaucratic costs. One of the provisions of the bill reads:

SPEECH.PARA: Reference materials, being specimens of materials or substances, one or more of whose property values are sufficiently homogenous and/or well established to be used for the calibration of an apparatus . . .

It is no wonder that tariffs are burdensome to the general community. It is no wonder that these things do, by and large, apply great extra costs to industry. Eventually these flow through to the exporting sector of our community. It is a little bit like sales tax, in the problems of differentiation between, for instance, strawberry Quik and chocolate Quik or between toothbrushes and toothpaste, on which sometimes sales tax falls and sometimes it does not.

PARA.TAB: The coalition policy on this whole question of tariffs has been somewhat misrepresented over the last couple of years. Our policy is to eliminate the rorts, the rackets and the rip-offs in the Australian economy. It is not to throw the textbook at every problem. At the last election, for instance, our policy was not zero tariffs; our policy was negligible protection by the year 2000. It did not mean no tariffs; it meant tariffs amounting to perhaps five per cent.

An example of the flexibility in our policy was provided just before the election by the special deal we gave to the sugar industry. The policy that the coalition took to the last election was designed to reduce protection and at the same time change the whole structure within which industry was operating so that the net operating costs of industry would be significantly reduced.

I contrast that with the general policy of the government to cut tariffs without at the same time establishing a lower cost environment in which industry can operate. In particular, while tariffs have been reduced steadily over the last few years, the government has not taken sufficient steps to deregulate the labour market, for the simple reason that the ghost at the cabinet table has always been the ACTU. The government's tariff reduction policy has, in effect, been a policy of unilateral economic disarmament. It has been a policy of inviting our competitors into a room to tackle our industries while both hands of our industries have been tied behind their backs.

I invite the government to show the same faith in the Australian workers as it has shown in the Australian industrialists. The government has taken the shackles of tariffs off industry and is allowing it to compete more freely, without allowing the workers to do the same. I invite the government to show the same zeal for deregulating the labour market as it has shown over the last few years for cutting tariffs and for deregulating.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Smith Mr Stephen

TALK.START.PARA: —I support the Customs Tariff Amendment Bill, which amends the Customs Tariff Act of 1987. This amendment bill relates to details in which, just as I have said previously in respect of excise tariff proposals, only aficionados take an interest in. The Customs Tariff Act of 1987 replaced the basis of our tariff classification system. That act replaced an existing classification system with the convention on the harmonised commodity description and coding description. I mention that because the 1987 bill was introduced by the honourable member for Lalor (Mr Barry Jones) in his then 1987 capacity as Minister Assisting the Minister for Industry. I happened to run into him in the corridor and I said that to try to find a bit of enlightenment for the Customs Tariff Bill I might mention his name. He told me that in the course of debate on that or a similar bill, because no-one was taking an interest, he said that the bill would be reviewed after 300 years. He wanted to see if anyone was listening! He said the result was that only Hansard was listening, no-one else.

PARA.TAB: In this bill there is a range of amendments with no central theme, but the amendments have underlying them some important policy issues and decisions. In a sense the devil is in the detail, but also the detail reflects some fundamental policy issues which have been at the forefront of this government's activities over the last 10 or 11 years. They can be summarised in three ways: firstly, ensuring that Australia becomes an internationally competitive country; secondly, pursuing micro-economic reform initiatives; and, thirdly—this relates in a sense to our international attitude—ensuring that we keep an eye out for developing countries less well off than ourselves.

Customs tariff is a duty or a tax levied on imported goods, in contrast to excise tariff, which is a duty or a tax levied on goods produced in Australia. So far as the particular amendments are concerned, there are four which the Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Industry, Science and Technology (Mr Lindsay) highlighted in the second reading speech and I will mention them briefly.

The first relates to Eritrea as a developing country. Honourable members would be aware that the Australian system of tariff preferences, or ASTP, provides preferential treatment to imports from developing countries. They receive a discount of five per cent off general industry assistance tariffs over five per cent, unless the general tariff rate is less than five per cent; and in such cases imports from developing countries enter free of duty.

It is interesting to note the figures for our balance of trade with developing countries. In 1989, Australian exports to developing countries were $17 billion, representing approximately 36 per cent of total exports. By 1991, Australian exports to developing countries had reached $21 billion, representing approximately 39 per cent of total Australian exports. Imports from developing countries in 1989 were $12 billion, or approximately 23 per cent of total Australian imports, and by 1991 those imports had risen to $13 billion, accounting for approximately 26 per cent of total Australian imports. So, in a sense, despite the preferental treatment, the balance of trade is in our favour.

So far as the preference scheme is concerned, in March 1991, in the industry statement, Building a Competitive Australia, the government announced that the margin of preference for goods from Singapore, Taiwan, Hong Kong and the Republic of Korea would begin to phase out from 1 July 1992. Subsequently, in the course of last year, the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) announced that developing-country tariff preferences would be modified for all but the least developed countries and South Pacific island territories. It is in that context that we see the addition through this bill of Eritrea.

The second amendment to which I wish to draw attention is in respect of the changes to the tariff rate so far as avgas and aviation kerosene are concerned. Underlying these amendments is an effort by the government to ensure that the activities of the Civil Aviation Authority, particularly in its safety area, are cost effective. Previously we have seen before the parliament amendments to the excise tariff regime which reflect those changes. The previous speaker, the honourable member for Warringah (Mr Abbott), referred to the change so far as reference materials are concerned, and the Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Industry, Science and Technology, in the course of his speech, referred to those changes made to textile yarns.

The importance of these amendments is very much reflected by the detailed policy arrangements or mechanisms that we find behind these measures. Before I comment on those policy measures, I think it is worth getting the revenue raising aspects of these measures in perspective. At page 4.224 of Budget Paper No. 1, in the indirect tax table, we find the sorts of revenue raising that are being referring to here. The 1994-95 estimate for customs duty is in the order of $3.2 billion. In relation to sales tax and excise duty, the sales tax estimate is $11.1 billion and for petroleum products the estimate is $9.7 billion. So, in customs duty, we are looking at a small proportion of the indirect tax that is raised. That amount has actually been falling over a period of time, and this reflects the underlying policy approach of the government.

The honourable member for Warringah referred to the tariff regime. Mr Deputy Speaker, we are in a very civilised chamber and so I will not labour the point—if I can put it that way—but a commitment to zero tariffs is a commitment to zero tariffs. It was significant that the new Leader of the Opposition, the honourable member for Mayo (Mr Downer), when allocating his front bench positions, decided that `Dr Zero', Dr Hewson, the person who absolutely committed the opposition to zero tariffs, would take the very important industry portfolio. I think that is most significant.

TALK.START.PARA: —He is on a holiday. He is on holiday on industry policy.

—He is on rest, but he is on holiday in industry policy. When the Main Committee comes to consider the amendments to the Industry, Science and Technology Legislation Amendment Bill we might give the former Leader of the Opposition the opportunity to clarify when zero does not equal zero. But we are in a civilised chamber and so I will return to the policy issues.

PARA.TAB: I have referred to Budget Paper No. 1 in terms of the revenue raising aspects. In terms of the policy, the most recent statement of government policy in the tariff regime area is found in the recent Working Nation statement. It contains a very succinct summary of what this government has stood for in terms of tariff policy in the course of the last decade. I refer to page 43 of the Working Nation statement. For the benefit of the chamber, I will read a couple of extracts:

SPEECH.PARA: Australia's program of tariff reductions remains one of the major achievements of microeconomic reform.

The general tariff rate will remain at a maximum of 5 per cent beyond 1996 and will make Australia's tariffs among the lowest in the world. The Government considers that this is an appropriate target for tariff reductions, and the clearly articulated schedule of changes provides certainty for these industries in developing business and investment strategies for the future.
And on following page it goes on to say:

Tariff and related arrangements for the passenger motor vehicles, and textiles, clothing and footwear industries, will remain fixed through to the end of the decade. They will be reviewed in 1996, with a decision taken in 1997 on arrangements to apply beyond the year 2000. The sugar tariff will remain fixed until 1995-96, with a review conducted in 1995-96 to determine levels for 1996-97 and beyond.
Developing Country Preferences will be phased out or removed for all but the least developed countries (including South Pacific Island Territories).
Of course, it includes Eritrea through this particular amendment. To continue:
This acknowledges the benefits these, and other countries, receive from Australia's unilateral tariff reductions.
And then, what in very many respects is the key point:

At the same time as tariff reductions have been taking place, our overall international competitiveness has improved by around 35 per cent. This shows that protection is only one element in the overall picture.

That is the key thing. It has been the effect of the government's tariff policies, combined with the effect of related policy, which has seen Australia change to an internationally competitive country. Australia has changed from being a country dependent on commodity prices, and the roller-coaster effect that that creates, to being a modern trading and industrial manufacturing country.

PARA.TAB: I do not propose to go further into the detail the amendments that I have referred to, other than to make some additional points in respect of the increases in the rates of duties on aviation gasoline and kerosene. I said at the commencement of my speech that there were, in a sense, three policy issues which underlined the detail of this bill. One was turning Australia into an internationally competitive country, and I have referred to the tariff regime. The second one was keeping an eye out for the developing countries less well-off than ourselves; and that is reflected in the comments that I have made on our developing-country arrangements. The third was micro-economic reform, and behind the changes to the rates of aviation gasoline and kerosene are the important reforms that we have made in the aviation industry.

I will not burden the chamber or the parliamentary secretary, who is very keen to get to the next bill, with the changes that we have made to deregulate the aviation industry, but I make some comments about the cost recovery efforts that we have made to ensure that the Civil Aviation Authority's safety efforts are cost recovered. I think that one of the best places to find the policy arrangements in respect of this is in the 1993-94 budget papers. The 1993-94 Budget Paper No. 1, at page 3.149, says:

SPEECH.PARA: The Government announced its intention in the 1992-93 Budget to achieve 50% cost recovery of the CAA's safety standards setting and surveillance functions by 1 July 1995. The Government will continue to fund 50% of these costs up to a limit of $22.8m a year. Phased recovery of the balance of safety standards setting and surveillance costs from the aviation industry commenced from 1 September 1993. The CAA will achieve full recovery by 1994-95—
and that of course has been taken up in the recent budget—
of the costs incurred in implementing safety standards.

As I said earlier, that effort is reflected in the changed arrangements that have been made through the excise tariff regime, and they reflect this government's commitment to micro-economic reform in an important industry.

PARA.TAB: For those reasons I support the amendments before the Main Committee. They are, in very many respects, technical and detailed amendments, but behind them we find key areas of activity that the government has taken to the Australian community after successive elections: turning Australia into a modern industrial trading nation; making sure that Australia is internationally competitive; doing that in a sensible way; rejecting the zero tariff approach of the opposition; and, importantly, ensuring that part of our thrust to become an internationally competitive country is a series of micro-economic reforms, one of which is reflected by the changes made in the aviation gasolene and kerosene amendments in this particular bill. I support the bill.

DEBATE.TITLE: INDUSTRY, SCIENCE AND TECHNOLOGY LEGISLATION AMENDMENT BILL 1994

PARA.TAB: Consideration resumed from 30 May.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lindsay The Hon E.J.

TALKER.NAME: Mr LINDSAY
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Industry, Science and Technology)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That the bill be now read a second time.

PARA.EMPHASIS: Amendment of the National Measurement Act 1960

SPEECH.PARA: The objects of the National Measurement Act 1960 include establishing a national system of units and standards of measurement of physical quantities and providing for their uniform use. The National Measurement Act is administered by the National Standards Commission, a Commonwealth statutory authority established in 1950.

PARA.TAB: This bill will amend the National Measurement Act by increasing the number of commissioners serving on the National Standards Commission, by giving the commission the power to invest its money and to provide financial assistance, and by making other changes of an administrative nature.

The commission currently comprises a chairperson, an executive director and six other members. The chairperson is usually an eminent scientist or technologist, while the members bring to the commission a great breadth of experience at a very senior level. These members represent high technology industry, CSIRO, consumer interests, the trade measurement industry, the National Association of Testing Authorities, trade measurement authorities and academia.

A program evaluation of the commission was carried out between December 1991 and March 1992 by Dr Kevin Foley. He was chosen by the Evaluation Steering Committee, which comprised representatives of the Department of Industry, Technology and Regional Development, the Department of Finance, the Bureau of Industry Economics and the National Standards Commission. Recommendation 6 of the evaluation report dealt with expanding the skills, perspective and experience of the commission by increasing its numbers by two to a total of 10 commissioners. This bill implements that recommendation.

The amendments allowing the commission to enter into contracts involving amounts up to $250,000 without ministerial approval, and allowing it to invest surplus funds resulting from cost recoverable activities, bring it into line with other similar government bodies. Provision of a granting power to the commission will enable it to make grants of financial assistance for purposes related to metrology. The amendments will result in one additional staff member at a total cost of $100,000 per year.

SPEECH.PARA: The amendment to the Patents Act 1990 brings that act in line with recent amendments made to the Seas and Submerged Lands Act 1973 by the Maritime Legislation Amendment Act 1994. The Seas and Submerged Lands Act now defines Australia's continental shelf by reference to the 1982 United Nations Convention on the Law of the Sea, not the 1958 Convention on the Continental Shelf. Consequential amendments to other Commonwealth legislation were included in a schedule to the Maritime Legislation Amendment Act 1994.

PARA.EMPHASIS: Amendment of the Pooled Development Funds Act 1992

SPEECH.PARA: The purpose of the amendment to section 24(5)(b) of the Pooled Development Funds Act 1992 is to extend the period for which the most recent audited accounts can be used to determine the value of the total assets of an investee business before a pooled development fund, or a PDF as it is sometimes known, invests from 12 months to 18 months. This change reflects the fact that audited accounts for the previous financial year are generally not available for up to six months into the current financial year.

PARA.TAB: Currently section 24 of the Pooled Development Funds Act specifies that the size of the investee company at the time of the initial investment by a PDF must not exceed $30 million in total assets. Section 24(5)(b) requires that the audited accounts, used to determine the value of the total assets of the investee business, must relate to a period that ended not more than 12 months before the investment is made.

The amendment of the period from 12 months to 18 months in section 24(5)(b) permits, where necessary, the use of the investee company's most recent audited accounts to determine the value of the total assets. At present PDFs are prevented from investing in investee companies for, typically, up to the first six months of any current financial year, because audited accounts for the previous year are not available. The other timing constraints of section 24(5) remain unchanged.

The amendment to the Pooled Development Funds Act 1992 will have no impact on Commonwealth expenditure. A detailed explanation of the changes made by the bill is contained in the explanatory memorandum. I commend this bill to the Main Committee. I move:
That further proceedings on this bill be conducted in the House.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Human Services and Health, upon notice, on 12 May 1994:

PARA.TAB: (1) What information has her Department gathered about public hospital waiting lists in each State.
(2) Is she able to say (a) what the size of the waiting list is in each State and (b) how the methodologies used to calculate the waiting lists vary in each State.
(3) Is she able further to say how each State administers its waiting lists with regard to the roles played by doctors and hospitals.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Lawrence The Hon C.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

PARA.TAB: (1) The Australian Institute of Health and Welfare (AIHW) has been contracted by the Department of Human Services and Health, under

ANSWER.PARA: the Hospital Access Program to implement the development, collection and publication of accurate, comparable and timely data on waiting times across different areas and specialties. The first comprehensive national waiting list report will be published late in 1994 following the development arrangements for the provision of comparable national information with State and Territory health authorities.

PARA.TAB: In March 1994 the AIHW released an interim report, using available (but inconsistent) data. The purpose of the interim report was to highlight deficiencies in current information systems and to clarify the issues where national consensus on counting rules would be necessary.

(2) Yes; the AIHW interim report provides figures on both the size of the waiting lists in all States except Queensland and the methodology used to calculate these waiting lists. (Queensland does not currently collect waiting list data centrally on a regular basis).
The AIHW obtained by census, data on the numbers on waiting lists from the States on the following dates.

ANSWER.PARA: 1 July 1993 31 July 1993 30 September 1993 November 1993

PARA.TAB: However, the data presented in the interim report is to be interpreted with care. While the estimates for the number of patients on public hospital waiting lists have been made for Australia, the underlying data are incomplete.
The question of data reliability will be addressed in the national report as the States will have agreed with the AIHW on standard definitions, collection processes and data sets.

(3) Under the Medicare Agreements the States and Territories are required to provide comparable national waiting list data to the Commonwealth. However, there is a wide range of practice in the administration of waiting lists based historically on individual hospital management practices.

The Commonwealth has funded a number of projects through the Hospital Access Program to assist hospitals to reform waiting list management. Most States and Territories now have policies in place that require hospitals to maintain elective surgery waiting lists that are regularly monitored and updated, acknowledging the importance of hospitals knowing the full extent of all doctors' waiting lists. In some States, it is now a matter of policy for hospitals to obtain full lists from their doctors.

In some States, doctors have been instrumental in the development of standard clinical urgency ratings for patients requiring elective surgery. This approach will help to shift the focus from the total numbers of patients on waiting lists to numbers of patients who are waiting inappropriately according to their clinical urgency. This will assist the Commonwealth and the States to identify and measure the real magnitude of the waiting list problem and to better target resources.
